definition: a mineral consisting of calcium carbonate. Aragonite is one of the more soluble forms of calcium carbonate and is widely used by marine calcifiers (organisms with calcium carbonate structures)
aragonite saturation state is commonly used to track ocean acidification because it is a measure of carbonate ion concentration
organic material such as kelp and sea grass that is cast up onto the beach by surf, tides, and wind.
of, relating to, or occurring at the bottom of a body of water (e.g. the bottom of the sea floor)
the variety of life in the world or in a particular habitat or ecosystem. Can be used to investigate the health of an ecosystem
a large group of aquatic animal species that have two shells (like clams, for example)
a specific form of chlorophyll used in oxygenic photosynthesis
Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary
a large category of animal species that includes crabs, lobsters, and shrimp
mysterious or obscure, organisms that hide in plain site or in hard to find areas are said to be cryptic
(chiefly of fish) living close to the floor of the sea or a lake.
neurotoxin that causes amnesic shellfish poisoning (ASP). It is produced by algae and accumulates in shellfish, sardines, and anchovies
Typically colonial invertebrates such as Bryozoans and Hydrozoans that grow on and over structures and/or other organisms
includes rod & reel, powered rod & reel or hook troll, but generally means trapping or potting, and gillnetting, where the catching implement is set, soaked and later retrieved
small fish that are preyed upon by larger fish in an ecosystem
any of more than 90 different types of roundfish, flatfish, rockfish, sharks, and skates off the West Coast.
(HAB) occurs when colonies of micro-algae grow out of control and produce toxic or harmful effects on people, fish, shellfish, marine mammals and birds
the animals living in the sediments of the ocean floor or river or lake beds
an invasive species is an animal or plant from another region of the world that doesn't belong in its new environment

an animal lacking a backbone, such as an arthropod, mollusk, annelid, coelenterate, etc. The invertebrates constitute an artificial division of the animal kingdom, comprising 95 percent of all animal species
a category of small crustacean species that are commonly found throughout the world's oceans
organisms visible to the naked eye (> 0.5 mm) that commonly inhabit the benthos, where they can be found buried in sediment or attached to a fixed substrate
a plant, especially an aquatic plant, large enough to be seen by the naked eye. Macrophytes in the sanctuary include seagrasses and algae
human-created waste that has deliberately or accidentally been released in a sea or ocean
small mesopelagic fish of the large family Myctophida
species that have recently been introduced to an ecosystem
a reduction in seawater pH, which causes the water to be more acidic. This chemical pathway is driven by excess cardon dioxide (CO2) being taken into the ocean from the atmosphere
the autotrophic components of the plankton community and a key part of oceans, seas and freshwater basin ecosystems

the word “plankton” comes from the Greek for “drifter” or “wanderer.” An organism is considered plankton if it is carried by tides and currents, and cannot swim well enough to move against these forces.
an acoustic technology used to map the ocean floor
the curved coastline of Southern California from Point Conception to San Diego. The area includes the Channel Islands and part of the Pacific Ocean
a method of fishing that involves pulling a fishing net through the water behind one or more boats
the impact of a ship on seabed or waterway side. In accidental cases, it is commonly referred to as "running aground"
